abstract.p: AXA SA's shares fall sharply after it reports 3.3 percent first-half rise in net income, lower than many analysts expected; net profit rose to 1.21 billion euros, or $1 billion, but property and casualty insurance income dropped 14 percent; graph (S)

block.p: Shares in one of Europe's biggest insurance groups, AXA S.A. of France, fell sharply after it reported a 3.3 percent first-half rise in net income, lower than many analysts had expected. AXA, which has agreed to sell the United States investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette to Credit Suisse, said that net profit rose to 1.21 billion euros, or $1 billion, but that property and casualty insurance income dropped 14 percent, largely because of weak results in Belgium and Britain.

Shares in one of Europe's biggest insurance groups, AXA S.A. of France, fell sharply after it reported a 3.3 percent first-half rise in net income, lower than many analysts had expected. AXA, which has agreed to sell the United States investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette to Credit Suisse, said that net profit rose to 1.21 billion euros, or $1 billion, but that property and casualty insurance income dropped 14 percent, largely because of weak results in Belgium and Britain.
